intro: Abutilon mollissimum var. sandwicense, commonly known as the Kauaʻi hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the island of Kauaʻi in Hawaii. It is characterized by its large, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink and red, often with a prominent yellow or orange center. The plant has broad, heart-shaped leaves that are covered in soft, fuzzy hairs, giving it a distinctive texture. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is typically found in coastal areas and lowland forests. This species is also valued for its ornamental qualities and is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon mollissimum var. sandwicense is primarily native to the Hawaiian Islands. This variant is found specifically on the island of Maui. It grows in the wetter, more mesic habitats of the island's uplands. The plant is adapted to the tropical climate and high humidity of the region. It is considered a rare and endemic species within its range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon mollissimum var. sandwicense was mainly introduced to Hawaii. It was brought there by early Polynesian settlers and later by European explorers. This plant is commonly found in coastal areas and lowland forests. It has become naturalized and is now considered an invasive species in some parts of the island. Its rapid growth and ability to thrive in various soil types have contributed to its spread.
